meanings.definition: To make a harsh, grating noise.
meanings.sent1: The old door would rark loudly whenever it was opened.
meanings.sent2: The rusty gate began to rark as it swung back and forth.
meanings.sent3: The cat tried to rark at the birds outside, thinking it could scare them away.
meanings.sent4: The car's brakes started to rark like a rusty machine struggling to move.
meanings.sent5: The wind made the branches rark against the window all night long.

meanings.sent1: The teacher would rark at the students who didn't do their homework.
meanings.sent2: She didn't mean to rark at him, but she was just frustrated.
meanings.sent3: He would rark at his computer when it froze, as if it could understand him.
meanings.sent4: The coach would rark at the players to push them to do better.
meanings.sent5: The boss would rark at the employees for being late to work.

meanings.sent1: The rark of the chainsaw echoed through the forest.
meanings.sent2: The old radio emitted a strange rark that made everyone jump.
meanings.sent3: The baby's toy made a funny rark that made him giggle.
meanings.sent4: The rark of the metal scraping against the floor was unbearable.
meanings.sent5: The sudden rark of the alarm clock woke him up with a start.
